results.title: In partnership with the people
results.creator_credit: John M. Bale and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description: Battery Point is one of the oldest parts of Hobart and the City Council is about to put into practice a development plan which will retain the character and charm of this area. Shows the signal station, the seamen’s cottages, the fine houses of the wealthy, Kelly’s Steps, St George’s Church and other historic items.

results.title: Echoes in Freestone
results.creator_credit: Ray Barnes, John M. Bale and Tasfilm Productions
results.brief_description: Using sounds from the past, over pictures of the present, the film glimpses a man’s life in pioneering days. Set in the historic town of Richmond, Tasmania, the film shows some of the classic colonial Georgian houses and churches, many of which date from the early days.

results.title: Along the Sepik
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, Frank Bagnall, Stanley Hawes, R. Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia today”.
Shows the duties and responsibilities of an Australian Patrol Officer in the Upper Sepik River area of New Guinea. With law and order they try to introduce education, health services, agricultural services and a wider political concept. The rugged mountains and diverse native tribes present innumerable problems - most important is to encourage them to live together peacefully.

results.title: An Agricultural Officer in Papua and New Guinea
results.creator_credit: William Shepherd, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Presents the work being done in Papua and New Guinea by the Department of Agriculture to produce better stock and crops, and the opportunities for young men in this field. Various special training and research centres are shown, including the veterinary laboratory, rubber experimental station, cattle breeding station, and extension centres where people are trained as Agricultural Field Assistants.

results.creator_credit_for_label: William Shepherd, Maslyn Williams, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board

results.title: The Computer Centre
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Joe Scully and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adults Learning”.
A teaching aid to promote group discussion on the apprehension adults feel in adapting to computer technology. Shows a group of trainees being taught the operation of punch cards as part of a session in the use of computers.

results.title: Aborigines of the Sea Coast
results.creator_credit: Charles P. Mountford, Dept of Interior and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: This film records the 1948 expedition to Arnhem Land sponsored by the National Geographical Society and the Smithsonian Institution. It shows the life of sea coast Aborigines at Yirrkala in the north-eastern corner of Arnhem Land. Demonstrates how, as children, they learn to handle canoes made from bark and as adults how they use them for fishing and hunting turtle. Shows how the canoes are made by stripping bark from a tree. The women of the tribe do the camp chores, collect firewood, make string bags, hunt goannas, and search for food plants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charles P. Mountford, Dept of Interior and Australian National Film Board

results.title: A (Darren Almond)
results.brief_description:
Darren Almond’s film and video works create a tension between stillness and movement. The experience of place takes on a strong resonance in Almond’s minimalist but emotionally charged settings, which explore space, time and human subjectivity.

As an elemental ‘landscape simply made up of air, liquid and gas in different states’, Antarctica is a location that has long fascinated Almond. In early 2002, the artist was invited by Mission Antarctica to crew for a month around the Antarctic Peninsula. A is his response to that journey, in which Antarctica represents ‘the axis of time and space, the axis of everything’.

Almond’s haunting film envelopes the viewer in an abstract world, devoid of human presence. Skimming the crystalline surfaces of the ice islands, A slowly reveals delicate variations in the landscape as ice meets water and sky. The near-silence of Antarctica is matched with a dreamy score and the sampling of real sounds-cracks and rips in the ice-that Almond recorded on his journey. The visual and aural experience of A is as much an interior, psychological journey as an exterior one to the ‘end’ of the earth.

(SW 30.03.05)

results.title: Hello
results.brief_description: ‘Hello’ is it me you’re looking for?’ A wildly imaginative love story about love across the digital-analogue divides. Can an almost obsolete cassette head speak the language of love with only fast forward and rewind to work with?

results.title: Blow-up
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: ‘Blow up’ is a visual pun. Austrian experimental film-maker, Siegfried Fruhauf, uses discovered footage of a man demonstrating mouth to mouth resuscitation on celluloid. The film is displayed in a way that show-cases the celluloid format as an object, rather than viewing the film with the content frame by frame. As the footage rolls the film is objectively abstracted with penetrating sounds of heavy breathing. As the ‘camera’ pans closer, the image takes over and we enter the film. It is our breath that now fills the image.
